comments.body: Why is this a Token rather than a TokenChecker?  It takes a token as an argument.

The package was authenticator which seemed to satisfy the naming convention for interfaces.  Was originally authenticator.TokenAuthenticator and I shortened.  Strong preference?

> On Oct 2, 2014, at 7:26 PM, erictune notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> In pkg/auth/authenticator/interfaces.go:
> 
> > +See the License for the specific language governing permissions and
> > +limitations under the License.
> > +*/
> > +
> > +package authenticator
> > +
> > +import (
> > -   "net/http"
> >   +
> > -   "github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/kubernetes/pkg/auth/api"
> >   +)
> >   +
> >   +// Token checks a string value against a backing authentication store and returns
> >   +// information about the current user and true if successful, false if not successful,
> >   +// or an error if the token could not be checked.
> >   +type Token interface {
> >   Why is this a Token rather than a TokenChecker? It takes a token as an argument.
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

I guess authenticator.Token is like cipher.Block.  You have to reverse the package and interface names to get a good name.  I don't like it at all, but I guess it is the Go way.  So, I guess leave it.

I mentally warred between brevity and slavish adherence to verbing interfaces.

> >   successful,
> >   +// or an error if the token could not be checked.
> >   +type Token interface {

Why is this a Request rather than a RequestAuthenticator?
